transcript.text: Recognizing what is and is not an export can be tricky, especially when you’re in the middle of a busy workday. Click on each image to check your understanding of what constitutes an export.

contentText.text: You may unwittingly break the law or violate trade regulations by failing to recognize your actions as exporting something. Exports can include:

instructionText.text: Select each image to learn more. To read the next, click the X to close the text box.
Click on Next (bottom right arrow) to continue.

popText.text:
Something shipped, carried across a national border or given to a person or entity in, from or holding citizenship from another country. For example:
  • product samples hand carried into another country
  • technical drawings shown to a citizen of another country, in your country or somewhere else
  • a factory or facility tour for someone who is not a citizen of the country where the factory is located

Export-controlled technical information provided to a person or entity in, from or holding citizenship from another country in hard copy or electronic format. For example:
  • by courier
  • by email
  • shared on the web
  • posted in a shared folder
  • exchanged during a video conference, plant tour or at a public conference
  • discussed in a chat room

Providing someone in, from or holding citizenship from another country assistance related to the development, production, use, operation, installation, maintenance, repair, overhaul or refurbishing of a product.
Transferring received products or technical information to another person or entity, even if in the same country.
